subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern
msgSnippet: ... Thou shalt have a test name if you want JUnit to invoke the test method. My usual choice is to override runTest() in my Parameterized Test Case class, so
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 11/13/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
> >
> > Elliotte,
> >
> > I've posted it here some time ago. Your example is missing the test
> > name:
> >
> > public DataDrivenTest(int i) {
> > super("testFoo");
> > this.i = i;
> > }
>
>
> What's the justification for this?

Thou shalt have a test name if you want JUnit to invoke the test method.
My usual choice is to override runTest() in my Parameterized Test Case
class, so that I can use the test name to label the test data some way;
otherwise, when 5 of 7 rows fail, the failures all have the same test name.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
